form.definition: noun U or u is the twenty-first letter of the English alphabet.

adjective If something or someone is ugly, it is not pleasant to look at. That building should never have been passed by the councilit's so ugly. I always felt that I was hideously ugly. My neck came out in an ugly rash.

adjective If a situation is ugly, it seems that there could be trouble or even violence. The crowd was in an ugly mood. Things were growing ugly, and I wished I'd stayed away. In an ugly development, children as young as ten have taken to carrying knives.
noun An ulcer is a sore on the outside or the inside of your body which bleeds and forms pus. The ulcers on his legs need to be dressed regularly. She's got a stomach ulcer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective ulcerated

form.definition: adjective The ultimate result of something is the final outcome, often after a very long process. My ultimate aim is to become a director of the company.
adjective Ultimate also means the most extreme possible case of something. To climb all the mountains in the Himalayas is the ultimate challenge.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb ultimately Ultimately I'd like to buy a house near the beach.

form.definition: interjection Um is used to represent the sound that people make when they hesitate in speaking. He's, um, rather a difficult character. Could you come next week, um, say on the 24th?
noun You use an umbrella to protect yourself against the rain. It consists of a long handle attached to a folding metal frame covered in cloth.
noun An umpire is the person who makes sure that a game such as tennis or cricket is played according to the rules.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORD is referee. ... WORD FAMILY verb umpire Who's umpiring the match?

form.definition: determiner In informal language, umpteen means very many. Poor Hilda, she's had umpteen attempts at getting her driver's licence but she keeps on failing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective umpteenth I couldn't face starting again for the umpteenth time.

form.definition: adjective If a decision is unanimous, everyone involved agrees that is what should be done. The vote was unanimous. We were unanimous that we should wait another month.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb unanimously They voted unanimously to re-elect her as chair.

form.definition: adjective If something is uncanny, it is so strange that it makes you think that it may be caused by something outside the natural world. Kimiko has an uncanny ability to pick who is the next person to marry. By an uncanny coincidence, he phoned just as I was talking about him. The similarity between them is uncanny.
noun Your uncle is the brother of your father or mother.
noun Your uncle is also the husband of your aunt.

adjective If you are unconscious, you are not aware of what is going on around you, usually because you are sick or injured. He was found unconscious on the street. She struck her head against the wall and was knocked unconscious.
adjective If you are unconscious of something, you are not aware of it. Nina continued to read, completely unconscious of the fact that everyone in the room was staring at her.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb unconsciously I fear that I may have unconsciously offended some of the guests.noun unconsciousness The patient lapsed into unconsciousness.

form.definition: preposition If something is under something else, it is beneath it and covered by it. He keeps his tennis racquet under his bed. Why don't you wear a singlet under your shirt?
preposition If something is under something else, it is lower than it in height. We have the picture hanging on the wall directly under the spotlight.
preposition If something is under something else, it is lower than it in amount. Children under 18 are not permitted to buy cigarettes or alcohol.

If something takes place under certain conditions or circumstances, it happens with those conditions affecting it or allowing it to take place. We can only employ him under the conditions stated in his contract.
adverb If you bowl underarm, you throw the ball with your arm in a position below the level of your shoulder.
adjective If food is underdone, it has not been cooked long enough.

verb If you undergo something unpleasant or difficult, you experience it. It happens to you. The patient underwent three operations in four days. The witness underwent hostile questioning. The apparatus is undergoing tests.
noun Undergrowth is bushes and other small plants that grow close together under trees. We had to clear a lot of undergrowth in the backyard of our new house.

adjective If someone is underhand, they are sly and secretive in the way they do things. There's nothing underhand about Julieshe really lets you know what she thinks! It was pretty underhand of him to go above me to my boss.

verb If you underline something written, you draw a line under it in order to draw attention to it. The teacher told us to underline any words that we didn't know and look them up in a dictionary. The word 'urgent' was underlined twice in red.

verb If you underline something that you say, you emphasise it. Let me underline that this must not happen again. Dentists underline the importance of regular brushing of the teeth. This incident underlines the necessity for regular fire drills.
preposition If something is underneath something else, it is below or beneath it.
noun The underneath of something such as a table or chair is the part that is closest to the ground and faces the ground. Don't bother painting the underneath of the tableit'll never be seen.
noun Underpants are a short piece of clothing worn by men and boys under trousers or shorts.
verb If you understand something, it is clear to you in your mind. Do you understand these maths formulae? I don't understand what she wants us to do.
verb If you understand someone, you see the meaning of what they are telling you. She spoke so fast that I couldn't understand her.
verb If you understand a word or a language, you know its meaning. I understand Italian but I can't speak it very well. I don't understand the word 'symptom'.

verb If you understand someone or something, you are aware of their nature and why they behave in a certain way. Teenagers often claim that their parents don't understand them. I can't understand what made her do it. I knew I could count on you to understand.

verb In formal language, if you say you understand something is the case, you mean that you have heard it or take it to be true. I understand you've not been well, Mr Gresham. I understand they're in financial difficulties.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective understandable The delay is understandable in view of the circumstances.noun understanding She has a good understanding of the issues. He nodded in understanding.

form.definition: verb If you understate something, you present it as being smaller or less important than it really is. It is an offence to understate your income for tax purposes. If anything, he has understated the problem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun understatement To call it unfortunate would be an understatement.

form.definition: verb If you undertake a task, you take on responsibility for it. In the interim I will undertake the role of acting manager. Are you aware of the scale of what you've undertaken?

verb In formal language, if you undertake to do something, you promise that you will do it. She undertook to repay her creditors. ... WORD FAMILY noun undertaking He gave me his undertaking it would be done.
noun An undertaker is someone whose job is to prepare the bodies of dead people for burial or cremation. They supply the coffin and make arrangements for the funeral.
noun Underwear is clothing such as pants, bras, singlets and petticoats which you wear under your other clothes.
verb If you undo a fastening, you release it. He undid his seat belt and stepped out of the car. I can't undo this zip. Can you help me undo the knots? She undid the top button on her blouse.
verb If you undo something that is fastened, you unfasten it. Undo the parcel and let's see what's in the box. He took off his tie and undid his collar.

verb If you undo something that has been done, you cause it to be as it was before it was changed. The psychiatrist is trying to undo the emotional damage that Ben suffered in childhood. After I'd made all the corrections he wanted me to go back and undo them!
verb In formal language, if you say something undoes someone, you mean it causes their downfall. His addiction to gambling eventually undid him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun undoing This small carelessness proved to be her undoing.

form.definition: adjective If you are uneasy about something, you feel anxious and worried about it. I felt uneasy about lying to my mother. I'm beginning to get uneasy about the delay.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun unease I felt a sense of unease at these developments.

form.definition: adjective If you are unemployed, you do not have a job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun unemployed The government announced a new initiative to help the unemployed.noun unemployment

form.definition: adjective An uneventful period of time has no important or interesting things happening in it. Our holiday was a little boring and uneventful.

adjective If something is unforgettable, it makes such a strong impression on you that you will never forget it. The scenery was absolutely breathtakingquite unforgettable. Thank you all so much for making my stay unforgettable.

noun A uniform is the special clothes that some people wear to show that they have a certain job or go to a certain school. Julio looks so handsome in his naval uniform. I walked past three girls in school uniform.

adjective In formal language, if you say that things are uniform, you mean that they are the same. They don't vary. The results were surprisingly uniform across the whole population tested. Along the wall was a set of uniform glass jars.

verb If you unify several things, you bring them together as one thing. We are trying to unify the accounts of the various witnesses to give us an overall picture of what happened. The sales and marketing departments will be unified in the new building.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun unification

form.definition: adjective A unilateral decision or action is taken by only one of the parties involved with a particular issue, without consulting the others.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb unilaterally He unilaterally decided to end the contract.

form.definition: adjective If you are uninterested in something, you are not interested in it and you don't want to know about it. I am completely uninterested in their problems.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this word with disinterested. ... WORD FAMILY adjective uninteresting The meeting was more than usually uninteresting.

form.definition: noun A union or trade union is an organisation of workers in a particular industry or group of industries which tries to improve pay and conditions for its members.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective union ...a union member. ...union dues.

form.definition: adjective If something is unique, it is very special and rare. Be very careful not to chip this vaseit's unique. She has a unique combination of talents for the job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb uniquely She is uniquely well qualified to take on the task.

form.definition: adjective If something is unisex, it is suitable for both men and women. 'Is this jumper for a man or a woman?' 'Either, it's unisex.'
noun If a group of people sing in unison, they are all singing the same note at the same time.
verb If a group of people do something in unison, they all do it together. We all shouted 'Happy Birthday' in unison. When their demands weren't met they left the room in unison.

noun A unit is a thing or person or a group that is regarded as a single complete thing. Our family is a close and supportive unit. I've completed the first three units of my course. You can buy the shelving in separate units and fit them together.
noun A unit is a fixed standard amount which is used in measuring some quality such as length or weight. In Australia we use metric units, but in the United States imperial units are used.

noun A unit or home unit is a set of rooms for a family to live in. Other words you can use for this are flat or apartment. Tony and Isabella rented for about a year and then bought a unit in Brisbane.
verb If two or more people unite, they join together in order to achieve something. Despite their differences, they united to oppose the planning application.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective united We are united on this issue.

form.definition: adjective If something is universal, it relates to everybody or everything. There was universal sympathy for his predicament. Crime is a universal problemit's not confined to particular suburbs. How universal is this problem? Has anyone else had trouble?

noun The universe is everything that exists. Many people believe that the universe must have been created by a divine being. Somewhere in the universe there may be other intelligent beings. Her whole universe had collapsed.

noun A university is a place of higher education where students study for degrees and research is carried out by postgraduate students, lecturers and professors. Shirin hopes to go to university. He graduated from university last year. ... A SHORTENED FORM of this, used in informal language, is uni. ... WORD FAMILY adjective university ...a university course. ...a university degree.

adjective If a person or thing is unknown, people do not know who or what they are, or they do not know about them. The security guard stopped the unknown man at the door. Thai cooking ingredients are still unknown to many Australians.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun unknown Fear of the unknown can be a barrier to progress.

form.definition: adjective In rather formal language, unlawful means 'not legal'.

conjunction Unless means 'if ...not'. If you say that something will happen unless another thing does, you mean that the first thing will happen if the another thing does not. I'll leave at eight unless I hear from you. I won't go unless he asks me to. Don't open the door unless you're sure it's me.
verb If you unravel something that is tangled, you make it straight and tidy. I had to stop and unravel the wool before I could get on with my knitting.

verb If you unravel a complicated situation, you work out what the situation is and get it clear. It took me some time to unravel what she was talking about. When he died we had a lot of paperwork to unravel.
verb If something that is knitted unravels, it comes apart because the thread is broken. The sleeve is unravelling all around the moth hole. She felt as though her life was unravelling.

adjective If something seems or feels unreal, you find it hard to believe it is really happening. Everything happened so quickly that it all seemed unreal. Her death felt quite unreal to me until the day of the funeral.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is unreal, you mean that it is fantastic or amazing. 'How was the movie?' 'Unreal!' They serve this unreal chocolate ice-cream.

noun Unrest is discontent among a body of people that may lead to trouble or even violence. The rioting is over but there's still a mood of unrest. Industrial unrest has lost millions of dollars in production.

adjective If you survive an accident or a bad experience unscathed, you are not injured or harmed by it. The car was a write-off, but amazingly the driver was unscathed. Fatima's had a rotten life, and yet she appears to have come through unscathed.
verb If you unscrew something such as the lid on a jar, you take it off by turning it round and round to release it. Could you unscrew this lid for me? It's a bit tight.

verb If you unscrew something from somewhere, you detach it by removing the screws that are holding it in place. You usually do this with a screwdriver. I unscrewed the mirror from the wall and put up a print in its place.
adjective Someone who is unscrupulous doesn't behave according to moral principles. They often act dishonestly. Some unscrupulous car dealers were selling stolen vehicles.
verb If something unsettles you, it disturbs you and makes you anxious or worried. I rejoined the party, but the telephone call had unsettled me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective unsettled I've been feeling nervous and unsettled lately.adjective unsettling I found the trial an unsettling experience.

form.definition: verb If you untangle something that is twisted or difficult, you untie the knots or twisted parts in it or you remove the difficulties from it. Jan carefully untangled all the wires at the back of the video. The accountant spent hours untangling his client's financial affairs.
adjective If something is unthinkable, it is too terrible or shocking even to think about. If the nuclear waste leaked out, the consequences would be unthinkable.
adjective If something is unthinkable, you can't imagine it ever happening. Julie is totally honestit's unthinkable that she could be the thief.
verb If you untie a knot, you pull apart the string or cord so that there is no longer a knot in it. You must untie your laces before you take off your shoes.
verb If you untie something, you release it by removing the string or cord that is holding it in place. After the robbers left he managed to untie himself and phone for help.

preposition If something happens until a particular time, it begins before that time and then ceases at that time. He continued to work as an artist until his death last year. The strike will last until the weekend at least.
conjunction If something happens until something else happens, it begins before that thing happens and then ceases when it does. I'll wait here until you're ready.

preposition If something doesn't happen until a particular time, it doesn't happen before then. That is the earliest time that it happens. I won't decide until tomorrow. We decided to put off the meeting until the next week.
conjunction If something doesn't happen until something else does, it doesn't happen before then. We won't start until Rob arrives. We can't do anything until we hear from head office.

adjective If something is unusual, it is rare. It does not happen very often or you do not find it very often. Earthquakes are quite unusual in Australia. It's unusual to find koalas so close to the city. The soup had an unusual taste to it. She likes unusual jewellery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb unusually We've had an unusually warm winter this year. He was unusually late for work.

form.definition: adjective If something is unwieldy, it is difficult to move or handle because of its size, weight or shape. The painting isn't particularly heavy, but it's unwieldy. The volumes of maps are large and unwieldy.
preposition Up means 'at or towards a higher place'. The hikers slowly made their way up the mountain.
adverb Up means 'higher' or 'towards a higher place'.
adverb Up can mean in a direction that is towards the north. The Prime Minister came up to Sydney from Canberra. When are you coming up to visit us?
adverb If prices go up, they increase. The price of paint went up 10% on 1 January.
adverb If you go up to someone, you move to a position next to them or close to them. Luigi came up to me in the street to say hello.
adjective If you are up, you are not in bed. Good morning, I'd like to speak to Michael if he's up.
adjective If a period of time is up, it is at an end. Time's upnext please.
up to (a) If something happens up to a particular time, it happens until that time. She looked after her sick husband right up to his death.
(b) If someone is up to something, they are secretly doing something they shouldn't be doing.
ups and downs Ups and downs are the mixture of the good and bad things that happen. Trent's broke now but he used to be a millionairehe's certainly had his share of ups and downs.
noun Your upbringing is the way you were brought up. It is the way you were taught and treated during your childhood. He had an unusual upbringing on an isolated station.

verb If you update something, you bring it up to date. You change it according to the way things are now. The information in this file needs updatinga lot of the addresses are no longer current. She decided it was time to update her image. Let me update you on what's happened.
verb If you upgrade something such as an appliance, you get a new one that has more features. Sometimes you can get a discount if you buy it from the same manufacturer as the old one.

noun An upheaval is a move from one place or job to another which causes a lot of disruption and inconvenience. We took six months to settle down after the upheaval of moving from Europe to Australia.
adverb If something moves uphill, it is going up towards the top of a hill or slope. It's very tiring running uphill.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downhill.

form.definition: adjective An uphill task is a very hard and difficult one. It will be uphill work getting the job finished by tomorrow.
verb In formal language, to uphold something means to support or maintain it. The Supreme Court upheld the decision of the lower court. We must uphold the rule of law.

noun Upholstery is the soft covering on chairs, lounges and sofas which makes them comfortable to sit on. It consists of stuffing covered with fabric. This fabric is suitable for upholstery, but it's too coarse for dressmaking. ... WORD FAMILY verb upholster The sofa was upholstered in blue velvet.

noun The upkeep of something such as a house or car is its maintenance. It is what you have to do to keep it in good condition and how much this costs. It was quite a bargain to buy, but the upkeep has been very expensive.
adjective If something is up-market, it is of superior quality and expensive. To celebrate, they decided to go out to an up-market restaurant.
Upon is a formal word for on.
adjective If something is described as upper, it is above or higher than something else. He lives in an apartment block on one of the upper floors. She had a large swelling on her upper lip.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is lower.

form.definition: have the upper hand If you have the upper hand in a situation, you are in a strong or dominant position. In the first half our opponents had the upper hand, but now we're beginning to fight back.
adjective If something is described as uppermost, it is above or higher than everything else. There is still some snow on the uppermost slopes of the mountain.

adjective If something is uppermost in your mind, it is what you are thinking about as the most important thing. As the truck skidded out of control, what was uppermost in Theo's mind was to try to avoid the oncoming car.
adverb If something is upright, it is standing in a vertical position and the right way up. Try to keep the bottle upright as the seal isn't very tight. At last we got the boat upright again.
adjective In formal language, if you say someone is upright, you mean that they are honest and honourable. Henry's always been an upright citizenI can't believe he'd be guilty of fraud.
noun An uprising occurs when a large group of people rebel against their government.
form.note: ... SIMILAR WORDS to this are rebellion and revolt.

form.definition: noun An uproar is the loud noise and shouting that a group of people make when they are very angry about something. The meeting ended in total uproar. I went out to see what all the uproar in the street was about. There was an uproar when the results were announced.
adjective If something is uproarious, it is very funny. I really recommend the movieit's uproarious. He told us some uproarious stories about his adventures in Europe.
verb If something upsets you, it causes you to feel unhappy or worried. It distresses you. The news of Wang's arrival has upset everybody.
verb If something upsets your plans, it makes it impossible for you to go ahead as you had intended. The storm upset our plans to go to the beach. This delay has upset our whole schedule.
verb If something such as food or drink upsets you, it makes you feel sick. All that rich food last night upset my stomach. I'm allergic to fishthe smallest amount upsets me for days.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective upset What's the matter with Michaela? She seems very upset.adjective upsetting It was a very upsetting experience for the whole family.

form.definition: adjective If something is upside down, it is the wrong way up. The part that is usually or meant to be at the top is at the bottom, and the part that is usually or meant to be at the bottom is at the top. You've hung the picture upside down. You have to put the pages into the copier upside down. I turned each card upside down as I dealt with it.
adverb If you go upstairs in a building, you go up to a higher floor than the one you are on. I went upstairs to fetch my glasses. 'Where's Judy?' 'She's upstairs in her bedroom.'
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downstairs. ... WORD FAMILY ...the upstairs bathroom.

form.definition: adverb If something moves upstream along a river, it moves in the opposite direction to which it is flowing. We rowed a little further upstream.

adverb If something is upstream of something else along a river, it is closer to the source. The old mill is a few kilometres upstream of the bridge. They complained about the pollution being discharged by the factories upstream.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downstream.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say someone is uptight, you mean that they are very tense and anxious about something. Stefan should learn to relaxhe's always so uptight. There's no point getting uptight about itit's really no concern of yours.
adjective If something is up-to-date, it is current and includes all the latest developments. Are all these files up-to-date? Have you got an up-to-date address for Carrie?

adjective If something is up-to-date, it is modern. It is fashionable or uses the latest technology. You should get rid of this old suit and get something more up-to-date. I want one of those up-to-date cameras with all the extra features.

noun An upturn is an improvement in the condition of something. In the last few months there has been a gradual upturn in the economy. We've experienced an upturn in our fortunes since we moved north.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downturn.

form.definition: adjective An upward movement goes from a lower place or condition to a higher one. We passed the other cable car on its upward journey. There has been an upward trend in property prices.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downward.

form.definition: adverb If something moves upwards, it goes from a lower place or condition to a higher one. Suddenly the lift shot upwards. The temperature crept steadily upwards as we drove north.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downwards.2 upwards of Upwards of a number or an amount means more than that number or amount. Upwards of thirty people came to the party. The paintings are priced at $200 and upwards.

form.definition: adverb If something moves upwind, it goes in the opposite direction to the way the wind is blowing. We tacked upwind to the island.
adverb If something is upwind of something else, the wind is blowing in the direction from the first thing to the second. The animal seemed to detect a predator upwind.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is downwind.

form.definition: noun Uranium is a radioactive element. It is used to produce nuclear energy and nuclear weapons.
adjective Urban means relating to a city or town. I longed to escape from urban life.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is rural.

form.definition: adjective If someone is urbane, they are charming and sophisticated. His urbane manner made him a welcome guest.
noun An urge is a strong desire or impulse to do something. I felt a powerful urge to ring her. I resisted the urge to strike him.
verb If you urge someone to do something, you try hard to persuade them to do it. I urged Arturo to think carefully before giving up his job.

adjective If something is urgent, it must be dealt with as soon as possible. The letter was stamped 'URGENT'. I must speak with Mr Tanaka on an urgent matter. Please ask Bridget to call me as soon as she get's init's urgent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun urgency This is now a matter of urgency. There was urgency in her voice.adverb urgently You're wanted urgently on the phone. I'm afraid I must go home urgently.

form.definition: noun A urinal is a type of toilet for men to urinate in.
noun Urine is the waste liquid that you pass out of your body at intervals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb urinate I felt an urgent need to urinate.noun urination I suffer from severe pain on urination.

form.definition: noun An urn is a large electric container used for boiling water to make tea or coffee for a large number of people.
noun An urn is also a kind of vase. It is often used to contain the ashes of dead people who have been cremated.
pronoun Us is the form of we that is used as the object of a verb or after a preposition. Our teacher gives us too much homework. That man is pointing at us!

dictionary.entry:
useju:z ; for senses 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7, /\times,0\jus/ (verb forms\optima0\usesusedusing
verb If you use something, you do something with it for a particular purpose. My pen's run outmay I use yours? I used tweezers to get the splinter out. How much detergent should I use? I can recommend the builder we used for our renovations.
verb If someone uses you, they take advantage of you. They get you to do things for them but they are not willing to do anything in return. Can't you see that they're just using you? You'll never get the proper credit for all your hard work.
noun If something has a use, there is a purpose for which it can be used. He keeps a lot of old junk just in case he finds a use for it one day.
noun If you have the use of something, you have permission to use it. I had the use of Julie's car for a month while she was overseas. Use of the tennis courts is included in the rent.
in use If something is in use, it is being used. Excuse me, is this washing machine in use?
no use If you say there is no use in doing something, you mean that it is pointless to do it. Doing it will not help at all. There's no use in complaining nowyou should have thought of that before. It's no use grumblingI'm not going to change my mind. What's the use even trying at this stage.
of use If something is of use, it is useful. You find it helpful or handy. Is this old vacuum cleaner of any use to you?
use up If you use up a supply of something, you use all of it so that there is none left. Who's used up all the toilet paper? Don't use up all the hot waterI want a shower too.
... WORD FAMILY adjective usable (<or> useable) The knife is so blunt that it's no longer usable.adjective useful Thanks for lending me the book on gardeningit was very useful.noun usefulness adjective useless It's useless expecting them to help. Her advice was useless to me.noun user The new model is very popular with users.

form.definition: verb If you used to do something, you did it regularly or for a period of time in the past, but you don't do it now. I used to catch the ferry to work, but now I take the train. I never used to like coffee, but now I've got quite a taste for it. How often did you use to visit him?

adjective If you are used to something, you are familiar with it. It isn't a surprise or a shock to you. Don't take any notice of Tren's tantrumsyou'll get used to them. It took me quite a while to get used to the climate. I'm not used to having to wear a suit to work.
adjective If something such as a car is described as used, it is second-hand.

adjective If something is usual, it is what most commonly happens. Today I got up earlier than my usual time. I felt bored with my usual activities. The usual way is to pay quarterly. I was even hungrier than usual.

as usual If you say that something happens as usual, you mean that it normally happens that way. There is nothing different or surprising about it. I left for work at seven as usual, but the traffic was so bad I didn't arrive until eight. Ricardo was late as usual!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb usually I usually go to the shops on Saturday. It's not usually so warm in July.

dictionary.entry: uteju:t noun Ute is a short form of utility truck.

form.definition: noun Utensils are things that you use when you are doing tasks in your home such as cooking. Note that this word is usually used in the plural form. You can be more efficient if you've got good kitchen utensils.
noun Uterus is a formal word for the womb.

dictionary.entry: utilitiesju:`tIl@ti:z <noun Utilities are resources, such as gas and electricity, supplied to consumers by public or private enterprises.

utility truckju:`tIl@ti: trV k <noun> A utility truck is a vehicle with an enclosed front for a driver and passenger, and a bigger back for carrying things. The back can be covered by a tarpaulin or uncovered.

form.definition: adjective In rather formal language, you can use utter for emphasis, to mean 'complete' or 'total'. To my utter amazement, I passed the maths test. She looked at me in utter disbelief. The whole trip was an utter disaster.

verb In rather formal language, if you say someone utters sounds or words, you mean that they express them with their voice. Marnie uttered a scream. The words were uttered in a whisper. He promised not to utter a word about the plan. She uttered the opinion that it was a lot of fuss about nothing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb utterly He seemed utterly astonished by the news.[fa[xp
